metadata.title: Nintendo Wii Fit and Balance in Older Adults
synonyms: virtual-reality-driven  balance training in older adults
nintendo wii fit balance training in older adults
exergaming balance training in older adults
active video games balance training in older adults
description: Nintendo Wii Fit (NWF) is designed to promote activity through interactive exercise games and has specific games that are designed to improve balance

NWF, a type of virtual-reality  exercise system, can provide sensory feedback (auditory, visual, and proprioceptive) to the individual participating in the exercise training program. The training program’s level of difficulty can be adjusted as the individual improves(3)

NWF and other gaming systems are relatively inexpensive and can provide greater patient compliance with the individual’s home exercise program due to increased interest and motivation in the prescribed activities

Results of preliminary studies indicate that NWF could be an effective adjunct to physical therapy or perhaps a standalone intervention for improving balance in selected older patients with a variety of disabling conditions; however, RCTs are lacking
Although more research is needed, NWF may also be of use for balance testing, either on its own or as an adjunct
This Clinical Review provides information on NWF video exergaming for assessing and improving postural stability and dynamic balance of older adults (≥ 65 years of age)
For additional information, see Clinical Review…Falls in Older Adults; Item Number: T708541
indications: Impaired ability to perform functional mobility and ADLs safely
Impaired static or dynamic standing balance

CPT codes.description: neuromuscular reeducation of movement, balance, coordination, kinesthetic sense, posture, and/or proprioception for sitting and/or standing activities

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement specifically for NWF balance training has been identified  Indications for procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Stop the examination and contact the referring physician if patient has a new or untreated fall-related  injury, or if the patient experienced loss of consciousness during a fall
Consult with physician in cases of active inflammation or apparent infection of unhealed wounds
Monitor for signs/symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stop evaluation and notify physician if signs of DVT or infection are present
Clinician should monitor for signs/symptoms of infection, including increased erythema, edema, and pain around unhealed wounds. Also, note any drainage from incisions
Clinician should follow up with the referring physician if patient presents with undiagnosed hyper-  or hypotension, changes in mental status, or signs/symptoms of anemia

indications for procedure: Indicated for patients who have impaired mobility, decreased lower extremity strength, decreased static or dynamic balance, or increased risk of falling

Authors of a 2020 prospective study have found that the Wii Fiit Balance board, particularly the yoga tree pose correlates similarly with the gold standard Sensory Organization Test. Therefore, the Wii Fit Balance Board is suitable for evaluating postural stability and may help reduce future falls in the geriatric population(19)

contraindications precautions: High fall risk–Can modify by providing upper extremity support or guarding
Fear of falling, especially in persons with disabling conditions
History of activity avoidance/restriction and/or mobility coping strategies
Dementia or other cognitive impairment that would impair the patient’s ability to follow directions and safely use

description of the nwf balance board for: The user stands on a stationary force plate platform
The platform has a strain gauge-type  load sensor mounted on each corner. The four load sensors estimate the user’s centerof pressure (COP)
Excursions of the COP are related to the control of balance in the exergame and displayed as movement of the avatar on amonitor or television
Instantaneous visual feedback makes the exergame interactive
using the nwf system in a clinical setti: Exergames found suitable for balance training of older adults were the Basic Step, Soccer Heading, Ski Slalom, PenguinSlide, and Table Tilt (see descriptions in Treatment summary , below)
More challenging exergames that might not be suitable for older adults include the Ski Jump, Balance Bubble, TightropeWalk, Snowboard Slalom, and Locus Focus
NWF exergames found suitable for balance training after stroke in older adults are listed in Treatment summary , below
The supervising clinician can choose the appropriate exergame for the goal training effect, as well as to match the patient’sage and physical ability
Assistance (e.g., gait belt, back of chair, or hands-on)  should be provided as necessary for high-risk  patients to prevent falls

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Is there a recent history of falls or near-falls?  If so, what injuries occurred at the time of the fall? -Does the patient lose balance because of environmental hazards (e.g., carpeting, obstacles, slippery surface), or does the patient lose balance without tripping (e.g., loss of balance due to compromised function)? -Is an assistive device being used? Is there a recent history of unexplained loss of consciousness? -Identify any risk factors (see below) that may contribute to reduced balance or postural instability. Has the patient changed his/her lifestyle or discontinued any activities due to fear of falling? Have there been any recent changes in vision, hearing, or sensation?

course of treatment.medical management: What is current weight-bearing  status? Document current conditions that might contribute to falls (e.g., vestibular disorder, vertigo, peripheral neuropathy, multiple sclerosis, and stroke). Has postural instability or ataxia due to degenerative cerebellar disease or other brain disease been diagnosed?
surgical management: Surgical management: Has the patient undergone any recent surgical procedures? In postoperative cases, inquire about any complications during surgery and patient’s current medical status
course of treatment.medications: Determine the current prescribed medications. Are they being taken on schedule? Are they effective? Medications that may contribute to falls include psychotropic drugs, some prescription analgesics, tranquilizers, antihypertensives, and arthritis medications. Analgesics are commonly taken for chronic pain
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Screening tests may vary depending on the patient’s underlying medical conditions:
Complete blood count (CBC), including hematocrit and hemoglobin, for anemia or infection
Ambulatory monitor when cardiac arrhythmias are suspected
Tilt-table  testing for patients with history of syncope/fainting
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors associated with increased risk of falling (e.g., dim/absent lighting, elevations)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms related to the fall (e.g., dizziness, lightheadedness)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess pain associated with fall injury -Activities-specific  Balance Confidence (ABC) Scale(6)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document factors and situations associated with increased fear of falling. For example, does the patient feel unsteady when rising from a chair, when standing or walking, when changing directions, or when reaching?
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night; does the patient wake frequently to use the bathroom at night?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could increase the risk of falls (e.g., dizziness, lower extremity weakness)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient use supplemental oxygen? -Does the patient experience shortness of breath? With exertion or at rest? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of falls?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other medical problems (e.g., diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, Alzheimer’s disease, rheumatoid arthritis, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, chronic kidney disease)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational sports or activities? Does the patient work? What are the job requirements? Are social or occupational activities affected by poor balance? Are there any activities that the patient avoids due to imbalance or fear of falling?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does patient use coping strategies to modify activity, or restrict/avoid activities because of fear of falling?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home or community; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. Is there a leg-length  discrepancy?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess patient’s need for ambulatory or adaptive device. If such a device has been prescribed, is it being used correctly? Check for fit and excessive wear and function of such features as hand brakes
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance in sitting and in stance –Berg Balance Scale (BBSA score below 45 on the BBS is associated with an increased risk for fall with a sensitivity of 66.6%(20)The patient makes a fist with right shoulder in 90° forward flexion and leans slowly forward as far as possible prior to loss of balance –Assess Romberg eyes open vs eyes closed, and in tandem if able –NWF Stillness Test(6)Assesses patient’s confidence and fear of falling during ADLs –Note preferred balance strategy(ankle vs hip vs step)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses in lower extremitiesAssess safety, ability, and need for adaptive equipment for general mobility (bed mobility, floor-to-stand,  sit-to-stand,  stair negotiation). Use the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test or FIM –Tinetti Performance Oriented Mobility Assessment(6)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait with the patient’s preferred cadence and at an increased speed. Assess patient’s step length, stride length, arm swing, step symmetry. Note any asymmetry or gait deviations (e.g., antalgic gait, Trendelenburg, shuffling gait pattern, decreased hip extension, decreased heel strike, decreased heel to progression) –The Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) or Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used –Assess speed with 10-minute  walk test (10MWT) –Assess gait in tandem walking if appropriate
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess trunk and bilateral upper and lower strength with manual muscle testing (MMT)  –Can assess functional strength with such tests as the 30-second  chair stand(5)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess standing posture, noting any asymmetry
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity active and passive ROM and flexibility
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Perform deep tendon reflexes (Achilles and patella), noting any hypo-  or hyperreflexiaAssess need for adaptive equipment (handrails, shower bench, raised toilet seat, cane or walker) to complete instrumental ADLs safely
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess bilateral lower extremity sensation to light touch and proprioception
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) –SF-36  or SF-8  Quality of Life –Choice Stepping Reaction Time (stepping on targets that are randomly illuminated)

other: Patients who use the procedure have balance problems and are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Postural instability with reduced static and/or dynamic balance; impaired use of balance strategies; increased risk for falls
assessment plan of care.rule out: Medical conditions associated with increased risk of falling (see Risk factors , above)
prognosis: Prognosis varies depending on the underlying diagnosis of the patient and the individual patient profile (e.g., comorbidities, cognitive status, patient’s age)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physician for review of medications that may impair balance (e.g., benzodiazepines, antidepressants, anticonvulsants, diuretics) Optometrist/ophthalmologist for vision assessment Audiologist to address hearing impairments Psychiatrist or cognitive psychologist for severe anxiety/depression, cognitive impairments Community center or gym for exercise-based  programs Physician or therapist specializing in vestibular disorders for a thorough evaluation Gerontologist
other considerations: Research on use of NWF for balance assessment: –Authors who conducted a study in Denmark concluded that the NWF Stillness Test is a low-cost,  objective, reproducible, and valid test of undisturbed postural balance in community-dwelling  older adults(6) -The agility test was also studied, but was found to have a learning effect and poor concurrent validity(6) –Researchers in Australia who conducted a study of 73 community-dwelling  older adults found that the NWF balance-board  derived anteroposterior sway velocity could be used in conjunction with existing clinical-based  measures in predicting future falls(10) –Researchers in the United States found that the NWF may be useful for low-resolution  measurements of balance, but should not be considered a replacement for laboratory-grade force plates(11) –Researchers in India who conducted a feasibility study found that the combined use of the NWF and Microsoft Kinect may be useful in providing real-time  visual feedback and monitoring during balance training in conjunction with non-invasive brain stimulation following posture disorders (e.g., Pusher syndrome)(8) -Ten community-dwelling  older adult subjects were included in the study
treatment summary: Balance impairments –NWF training program in healthy adults can increase anterior tibialis and medial gastrocnemius muscle activation following a 6-week  training program(3)  -Based on a study conducted in South Korea that included 24 normal adults (mean age, 21.9 years) -Subjects were placed in either the NWF training group or a traditional stable surface exercise group -Subjects participated in training program 3 times a week for 6 weeks -Muscle activity was measured with electromyography. There was a statistically significant increase in muscle activation in the anterior tibialis and medial gastrocnemius in the NWF group, but only an increase in the medial gastrocnemius in the traditional program -The authors concluded that this training can improve ankle stability since the muscles that improved are those used for ankle strategy -Researchers did not compare gains in muscle activation between groups and there was no increase in muscle activation of core muscles that were measured (erectae spinae and rectus abdominus) –The Wii-Fit  exercise program has been shown to improve the balance in community dwelling veterans(21) -Thirty community dwelling veterans were randomized to either the exercise group or control group -The exercise group trained for 45 minutes, three days a week for 8 weeks using the Nintendo Wii fit performing exercises on 5 categories: Yoga, strength training, aerobics, balance games, and training plus. The games included the table tilt, balance bubble, ski slalom, penguin slide, and tight rope walking -The control group performed cognitive based exercises for 45 minutes, three times a week for 8 weeks -Results show a significant difference in BBS scores for the experimental group versus control group –Authors of an RCT study compared the effects of a supervised balance training program compared to an unsupervised at home Wii-fit  based exercise program and found that both groups showed significant improvements in lowering fall risks, suggesting that the Wii-fit  exercise program can be just as beneficial when performed at home versus at a supervised clinic setting(22) -Sixty five older adults with type 2 DM were randomly assigned to either the supervised balance group (n = 34) or Nintendo Wii-fit  group (n = 31) -The supervised group performed their respective activity for 40 minutes, once a week for 12 weeks. Exercises included heel-toe  walking, calf- raises, forward leans, single limb balance, and basic yoga stretches -The Nintendo Wii-fit  group performed their exercises for 40 minutes using the Wii Fit Balance system, 3x/ week for 12 weeks. Games included aerobics, yoga, strength training, and balance -Results showed a significant reduction in reducing falls in both groups –Researchers of an RCT in Italy concluded that NWF is effective for improving balance in women over 65 years of age with osteopenia(13) -Participants included 38 female patients with a baseline reduction in balance as measured by the BBS (< 45) and presence of decreased bone density as measured by DEXA scan -Patients were randomly assigned to receive NWF sessions or conventional balance exercises. Both groups received interventions for 1 hour, 2 days per week, for 8 weeks -The NWF group exercises included center of gravity activities, yoga, lower extremity strengthening, and balance games (i.e., Balance Bubble, Ski Slalom, and Table Tilt) -The conventional balance exercises included stretching, strengthening of core muscles and gluteal muscles, balance exercises on unstable platform, and postural exercises in supine -After 8 weeks, significant improvement was noted in BBS scores in the NWF group compared to the control group. Significant improvement was also found in the SF-36  physical activity scores compared to the control group. Fear of falling (Short-form  Falls Efficacy Scale)was not different between groups –Studies have also shown that a 6- week unsupervised Wii balance program can be an effective modality for improving balance for the independent senior population and had significant improvements in the TUG, single limb balance, lateral reach, as well as gait speed(18)

Improving balance in community-dwelling  adults –NWF can improve the balance of independent older adults in an unsupervised setting, especially medial-lateral stability(5) -Forty-one  older adults (mean age, 74.5 years) recruited from retirement villages and local adult education facility -Participants in NWF group attended an orientation to receive instructions and to make sure they could use game safely. Participants in control encouraged to continue with regular activities. All participants contacted for follow-up  every 2 weeks by lead researcher  -Participants in NWF group encouraged to complete 3x30 minute sessions per week for 6 weeks (total of 18 sessions). They were also encouraged to use NWF in pairs, use a logbook, and record adverse effects such as slips, trips, and discomfort while using -NWF games encouraged to play were Soccer Heading, Penguin Slide, Ski Slalom, Ski Jump, Table Tilt, Snowball Fight, Perfect 10, and Tightrope Walking -Results showed good adherence to attendance (average of 17.5 sessions) and no adverse effects -NWF group demonstrated significant improvement in five clinical tests when compared to controls (TUG test, lateral reach in both directions, single-leg standing on left leg, and gait speed). No significant improvement was seen in Functional Reach Test, single-leg  standing on right leg, 30-second chair stand, and fear of falling as measured by Iconographical Falls Efficacy Scale (Icon FES) –NWF is a valid and safe tool for improving postural control and gait in older frail adults(15) –Results of a 2018 RCT study of 65 year old adults with type II diabetes while participating in a 12 week study have concluded that utilizing the Wii Fit- exercise program led to a decrease in falls which improved overall reaction times, lower limb proprioception, and general balance ability(16) -Sixty five older adults with Type II DM were randomized to either the experimental group or control group -Study continued for 12- weeks for 40 – minute sessions

Neurological rehabilitation –Authors of a prospective RCT conducted in the United States concluded that the NWF can be utilized to improve balance in community dwelling older veterans(14) -Thirty community-dwelling  veterans were equally randomized as part of an 8-week  study to determine the effects of NWF on balance -Objective measures used in this study were the BBS, subjective measures of fear of falling, physical activity enjoyment, and quality of life and were measured at baseline, at 4 weeks, and at 8 weeks -Groups participating in the NWF exercise group showed significant improvements on the BBS after 8 weeks compared to the control group –Researchers who published a systematic review with meta-analysis  in 2015 found that exergaming might be an appropriate therapeutic tool for improving balance and postural control in older adults, but that more large-scale trials are needed to determine if this is also the case for patients with idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (IPD)(7) –Researchers who published a systematic review in 2014 found that exergaming is feasible in patients with Parkinson’s disease; however, more research is needed to establish its safety and clinical effectiveness, especially for use in the home(9) –Researchers in the United States who conducted a small study on the effects of dual-task  training on patients with chronic stroke with hemiparesis found significant improvements in balance, reaction time, postural control, and cognitive abilities, as well as a decrease in cognitive-motor  interference(12) -Eight community-dwelling  individuals with chronic stroke participated -Intervention: cognitive-motor  training consisted of the performance of the NWF in conjunction with cognitive training (e.g., memory tasks) -Researchers advise that more studies with larger sample sizes are needed –United States researchers evaluated the effectiveness of using the NWF to increase physical activity levels in adults with multiple sclerosis(4) -Thirty adults participated in a 14-week  NWF home exercise program -Subjects were interviewed pre and post treatment intervention -Subjects reported that the NWF program helped build confidence in their abilities to achieve their goals related to leisure activities and reduce anxiety associated with participating in exercises at a gym -Subjects also reported initial concerns regarding fear of falling using NWF -Researchers concluded that NWF was limited in its customizability to accommodate subjects’ different functional levels

Strength –Authors of a 2016 RCT study conducted in Taiwan have suggested that the Wii Fit balance game can improve static balance and lower extremity strength in individuals with intellectual disabilities(17) -Twenty-  four students with an intellectual disability were randomized to either the Wii Fit balance group (n = 8), sedentary group (n = 8), or physical education group (n = 8)  -Those in the Wii Fit balance group participated in an 8 week, 40 minute session twice a week. Physical education group underwent standard physical education that consisted of jogging and jump roping -Objective measures used in this study included the TUG, single limb stance, and speed strength index -Results indicate that those in the Wii Fit balance group had significant improvements in all of the objective measures including the one leg stance, moving speed, TUG, and speed strength index. Those in the PE group showed improvements but were not considered significant .
